content.question: Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.The zebra mussel is originally native to the Black and Caspian Seas of Asia. Zebra mussels were first detected in the Hudson River of New York in 1991. Before the arrival of zebra mussels, the Hudson River supported populations of native unionid mussels.(a) Describe one way an invasive species, such as the zebra mussel, can decrease the carrying capacity for a native species in an ecosystem.

frqParts.text: Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.The zebra mussel is originally native to the Black and Caspian Seas of Asia. Zebra mussels were first detected in the Hudson River of New York in 1991. Before the arrival of zebra mussels, the Hudson River supported populations of native unionid mussels.(a) Describe one way an invasive species, such as the zebra mussel, can decrease the carrying capacity for a native species in an ecosystem.

b) Identify one characteristic of an <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></math>-selected species that could increase the likelihood of the <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></math>-selected species being a more successful invasive species than <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></math>-selected species.

(c) The table below shows changes in the population densities of zebra and unionid mussels from 1991-2015, in six year intervals.Native Unionid and Zebra Mussel Density in the Hudson RiverYearZebra Mussel <math alttext="open parenthesis, density per meters squared, close parenthesis"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>Unionid Mussel <math alttext="open parenthesis, density per meters squared, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>19910819973,250220032,500220092,000220152,7503(i) Based on the data shown in the table, calculate the percent change in the population density of unionid mussels from 1991 to 1997. Show your work.
(ii) Based on the pattern shown in the table, calculate the percent change in the population density of zebra mussels from 2009 to 2015.
(d) Scientists want to reduce the population of zebra mussels in the Hudson River.(i) Propose a solution for reducing the zebra mussel population in the Hudson River.
(ii) Describe one potential negative ecological consequence of your proposed solution for reducing the zebra mussel population in the Hudson River.

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Describe environmental concepts and processes.
